Package database

Class DatabaseAccess

java.lang.Object
database.DatabaseAccess
public class DatabaseAccess
extends java.lang.Object

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    DatabaseAccess()
    Constructor that sets timezone, allows multiple queries for the db and sets OS dependent location to save db-connection data

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    boolean checkTables()
    Checks if all necessary tables exist and creates them if not
    boolean closeConn()
    Makes closing a connection a one-liner and handles exceptions
    boolean completeReset()
    Completely drops the database and sets up a fresh one with initial data
    boolean createInitialData()
    Fills the DB with initial data, e.g. colors: Green, Red, Blue, Yellow Cleanses the tables from old data to avoid primary key conflicts before inserting
    java.lang.String createTimestamp()
    Creates a Timestamp of the current system time and converts it to a String that fits the mysql timestamp format
    boolean deleteSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
    Does the same as executeSQL, this method just exists for readability when executing statements
    boolean executeSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
    This is the method to use for executing statements (e.g. drop table, create table etc.)
    boolean getLastConTest()
    Returns the value of the last connection test (true if successful)
    java.util.prefs.Preferences getServerPrefs()
    Delivers the current server preferences
    java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object>> getTableNames()
    Gets the names of all existing tables in the current database Calls resultSetToArrayList to store them in an ArrayList
    boolean insertSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
    Does the same as executeSQL, this method just exists for readability when executing statements
    boolean openConn()
    Makes opening a connection a one-liner and handles exceptions Overloaded with two versions Version without parameters uses data in prefs to open connection
    boolean openConn​(java.lang.String protocol, java.lang.String db_url, java.lang.String port, java.lang.String db_name, java.lang.String user, java.lang.String pass)
    Version that uses parameters to open a connection Parameters are self-explanatory
    java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object>> resultSetToArrayList​(java.sql.ResultSet rs)
    Converts a ResultSet to an ArrayList Each entry in ArrayList resembles a row of the database resultSet (as a Map) Each Map holds the column name as a key (String) and the database entry as a value (Object)
    java.util.ArrayList<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object>> selectSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
    Provides a comfortable way to send select-queries.
    boolean setServerPrefs​(java.lang.String protocol, java.lang.String db_url, java.lang.String port, java.lang.String db_name, java.lang.String user, java.lang.String pass)
    Stores information for db connection in preferences, handles OS storage automatically Returns true if connection can be established, otherwise false Parameters are self-explanatory
    boolean testCon()
    Returns true if connection can be established

    Overload of testCon to test connection with other data than in preferences Parameters self-explanatory
    boolean updateSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
    Does the same as executeSQL, this method just exists for readability when executing statements

  • Constructor Details

    • DatabaseAccess

      public DatabaseAccess()
      Constructor that sets timezone, allows multiple queries for the db and sets OS dependent location to save db-connection data

  • Method Details

    • openConn

      public boolean openConn()
      Makes opening a connection a one-liner and handles exceptions Overloaded with two versions Version without parameters uses data in prefs to open connection
      Returns:
      true if connection can be established, otherwise false

    • openConn

      public boolean openConn​(java.lang.String protocol, java.lang.String db_url, java.lang.String port, java.lang.String db_name, java.lang.String user, java.lang.String pass)
      Version that uses parameters to open a connection Parameters are self-explanatory
      Parameters:
      protocol - The protocol used for the database connection, e.g. mysql
      db_url - The ip-address of the database server
      port - The port used, e.g. 3306
      db_name - The name of the database
      user - The username
      pass - The password
      Returns:
      true if connection can be established, otherwise false

    • closeConn

      public boolean closeConn()
      Makes closing a connection a one-liner and handles exceptions
      Returns:
      true if connection can be closed, otherwise false

    • selectSQL

      public java.util.ArrayList<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object>> selectSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
      Provides a comfortable way to send select-queries. Gets results as ArrayList. Handles exceptions and closes the statement.
      Parameters:
      sql - the query for the statement
      Returns:
      false if exceptions get catched, otherwise true

    • executeSQL

      public boolean executeSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
      This is the method to use for executing statements (e.g. drop table, create table etc.) Handles exceptions and closes the statement.
      Parameters:
      sql - the query for the statement
      Returns:
      false if exceptions get catched, otherwise true

    • insertSQL

      public boolean insertSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
      Does the same as executeSQL, this method just exists for readability when executing statements
      Parameters:
      sql - the query for the statement
      Returns:
      false if exceptions get catched, otherwise true

    • updateSQL

      public boolean updateSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
      Does the same as executeSQL, this method just exists for readability when executing statements
      Parameters:
      sql - the query for the statement
      Returns:
      false if exceptions get catched, otherwise true

    • deleteSQL

      public boolean deleteSQL​(java.lang.String sql)
      Does the same as executeSQL, this method just exists for readability when executing statements
      Parameters:
      sql - the query for the statement
      Returns:
      false if exceptions get catched, otherwise true

    • resultSetToArrayList

      public java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object>> resultSetToArrayList​(java.sql.ResultSet rs) throws java.sql.SQLException
      Converts a ResultSet to an ArrayList Each entry in ArrayList resembles a row of the database resultSet (as a Map) Each Map holds the column name as a key (String) and the database entry as a value (Object)
      Parameters:
      rs - The resultSet that a select-statement delivers
      Returns:
      An ArrayList that contains a map for each entry in the resultSet
      Throws:
      java.sql.SQLException - Since the resultSet directly accesses the db when getting called to pull data every call can throw a SQLException if there is no connection (anymore).

    • setServerPrefs

      public boolean setServerPrefs​(java.lang.String protocol, java.lang.String db_url, java.lang.String port, java.lang.String db_name, java.lang.String user, java.lang.String pass)
      Stores information for db connection in preferences, handles OS storage automatically Returns true if connection can be established, otherwise false Parameters are self-explanatory
      Parameters:
      protocol - The protocol used for the database connection, e.g. mysql
      db_url - The ip-address of the database server
      port - The port used, e.g. 3306
      db_name - The name of the database
      user - The username
      pass - The password
      Returns:
      true if the connection test at the end of the method is successful, otherwise false

    • getServerPrefs

      public java.util.prefs.Preferences getServerPrefs()
      Delivers the current server preferences
      Returns:
      the Preferences stored at the location determined in the constructor

    • testCon

      public boolean testCon()
      Returns true if connection can be established
      Returns:
      true if a connection can be opened, otherwise false

    • testCon

      public boolean testCon​(java.lang.String protocol, java.lang.String db_url, java.lang.String port, java.lang.String db_name, java.lang.String user, java.lang.String pass)
      Overload of testCon to test connection with other data than in preferences Parameters self-explanatory
      Parameters:
      protocol - The protocol used for the database connection, e.g. mysql
      db_url - The ip-address of the database server
      port - The port used, e.g. 3306
      db_name - The name of the database
      user - The username
      pass - The password
      Returns:
      true if a connection with given parameters can be opened, otherwise false

    • getLastConTest

      public boolean getLastConTest()
      Returns the value of the last connection test (true if successful)
      Returns:
      Last result of a connection test (.testCon())

    • getTableNames

      public java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object>> getTableNames()
      Gets the names of all existing tables in the current database Calls resultSetToArrayList to store them in an ArrayList
      Returns:
      an ArrayList in the format described at resultSetToArrayList() containing the names of all tables in the db

    • checkTables

      public boolean checkTables()
      Checks if all necessary tables exist and creates them if not
      Returns:
      true if all tables are there or if all necessary tables can be created

    • createInitialData

      public boolean createInitialData()
      Fills the DB with initial data, e.g. colors: Green, Red, Blue, Yellow Cleanses the tables from old data to avoid primary key conflicts before inserting
      Returns:
      true if all insert statements can be executed without returning false, otherwise false

    • completeReset

      public boolean completeReset()
      Completely drops the database and sets up a fresh one with initial data
      Returns:
      true if all steps to a complete reset were successful, otherwise false

    • createTimestamp

      public java.lang.String createTimestamp()
      Creates a Timestamp of the current system time and converts it to a String that fits the mysql timestamp format
      Returns:
      the converted timestamp as a String
